1: <sup>1</sup> Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?
2: <sup>2</sup> The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the LORD, and against his anointed, saying,
3: <sup>3</sup> Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.
4: <sup>4</sup> He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh: the LORD shall have them in derision.
5: <sup>5</sup> Then shall he speak unto them in his wrath, and vex them in his sore displeasure.
6: <sup>6</sup> Yet have I set my king upon my holy hill of Zion.
7: <sup>7</sup> I will declare the decree: the LORD hath said unto me, Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee.
8: <sup>8</sup> Ask of me, and I shall give thee the heathen for thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.
9: <sup>9</sup> Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron; thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter’s vessel.
10: <sup>10</sup> Be wise now therefore, O ye kings: be instructed, ye judges of the earth.
11: <sup>11</sup> Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling.
12: <sup>12</sup> Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way, when his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.
